Description: Reconstructed South Ionian pottery cup with everted rim (mended from fourteen fragments); top of lip reserved; interior: lip glazed with reserved band at base; broad black band on wall; sets of dilute lines on floor, interspersed with two black bands; black ring at centre; top of rim glazed; exterior: lip and top of wall reserved; reserved bands in handle zone and on lower wall; outside of foot glazed; 'brush wipes' on stand surface; reserved on underside.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2 (possibly)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Although Schlotzhauer (Schlotzhauer 2012) does not discuss this sherd, the profile and decoration find parallels with his South Ionian cups with everted rim Type 9A. The type closely follows the shape and decoration of the Attic Plain Komast cups. These cups coincide with Petrie’s class L1 (Petrie 1886, 18), Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type VIII (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116), and Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88). Type 9 cups have been found in large numbers in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus and the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra. This type was the most common type of South Ionian cups with everted rims found at Naukratis. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.280) (Phase 3)
